harm than good by putting him on -—and perhaps hundreds of listeners who might be
potentially interested, tune over to another station.
How often do you make this kind of compromise? I know that we still do, more often
than we should. And I’d say, better we should schedule a series on ancient Roman
band instruments, if we can find a scholar with a dynamic, challenging way of
presenting his material.
How many of us produce beyond our limitations? How often, with a handfull of half-
trained speech majors and limited studio facilities, do we try to present a big-
time, elaborate historical documentary on, say, freedom of speech.
Does the material get across when our listening audience is predominantly conscious
of the fact that a bunch of teen-ave kids are trying to make like John Peter Zenger?
I say that our growing audience of discriminating listeners won't be that tolerant
any more. They’ve come to expect too much from us, by way of the better NAEB Net¬
work offerings. If, between a program in the"Ways of Mankind’’ series and the fol¬
lowing locally produced program, the level of quality drops from the sublime to
the ridiculous, the local station looks that much more amateur and inadequate to do
the job it professes to be doing.
Let’s program within our existing budgets and our existing limitations. Let's not
have any unfounded illusions about our potential ability to compete with elaborate
network production. And on the other hand, let's not settle for poor speakers.
I'm not implying that we shouldn't constantly be working on increasing our capacity
to produce bigger and better "Ways of Mankind" or "Jeffersonian Heritages" at the
local level. But start in a closed-circuit situation. Have workshops in writing,
production, and acting. But until you've got a production you know is top-grade,
don't impose it on your audience. Concentrate instead on presenting your best re¬
sources in other than dramatic format.
I know I'm approaching an area of conflicting opinion here. I've many times heard
the argument, at NAEB gatherings, that one of our primary jobs is to train students
in radio-that on-the-air experience is a vital part of that training.
But I think we, as a communications industry, have out-grown that doctrine. I'd say
the potential audience we can command now is more important than the half-trained
student whogsts to play Galileo on the air with an immature voice and a technique
that isn't up to the demands of a first-cldss production. Let him knock himself
out in a closed-circuit workshop. But until he can compete in performance with the
networks, keep him off the air.
And while we’re on the general subject, I think we should make an increased effort
toward more NAEB seminars and workshops for people at the working level-seminars
for writers, for producers. We have too many, I think, at the administrative level,
without regard for the people who are actually putting programs on the air, day in
and day out. What your situation is, I don't know-but I know that my gang at
KCJOi-i would give their eye teeth for a seminar on production or writing or community
relations. A chance to talk shop and compare techniques and formats. A chance to
get some new ideas from some top-level writers and producers in the industry.
So there's Point Number One-an increased effort toward up-grading of standards
of presentation to meet the demands of an increasing audience.
